body:
In order to smoothly transition to the vim.lsp.start interface in the future, adding checkhealth here is meaningless(because we already have checkhealth of lsp).  So shown deprecate servers list in LspInfo and update the server deprecate remove version to 0.2.1. 0.2.0 is tagged too quickly cause some servers not removed.


![QQ_1726571465599](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d2114e66-e049-4dd8-b79b-c06ecec96709)


cc @tskj

comment_data.body: this seems kind of strange. why not define `M.server_alias` ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -7,41 +7,45 @@ local M = {
 ---@class Alias
 ---@field to string The new name of the server
 ---@field version string The version that the alias will be removed in
----@param name string
----@return Alias
-local function server_alias(name)
-  local aliases = {
-    ['fennel-ls'] = {
-      to = 'fennel_ls',
-      version = '0.2.0',
-    },
-    ruby_ls = {
-      to = 'ruby_lsp',
-      version = '0.2.0',

-      version = '0.2.0',

-

-end
+---@field inconfig boolean need shown in lspinfo

+    to = 'fennel_ls',
+    version = '0.2.1',
+    inconfig = false,
+  },
+  ruby_ls = {
+    to = 'ruby_lsp',
+    version = '0.2.1',
+    inconfig = false,
+  },
+  ['starlark-rust'] = {

+    version = '0.2.1',
+    inconfig = false,
+  },

+  },
+  tsserver = {
+    to = 'ts_ls',
+    version = '0.2.1',
+    inconfig = false,
+  },
+}
 
 local mt = {}
 function mt:__index(k)
+  if k == 'server_alias' then
+    return aliases

comment_data.body:
doesn't lspinfo.lua already show the "current connected" servers? why do we need to store state in `inconfig`, instead of just using `server_alias()` here just-in-time to see if a currently-connected server is deprecated?

calculating just-in-time is better than storing state.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -264,12 +264,22 @@ return function()
     end
   end
 
+  local available_servers = util.available_servers()
   local matching_config_header = {
     '',
-    'Configured servers list: ' .. table.concat(util.available_servers(), ', '),
+    'Configured servers list: ' .. table.concat(available_servers, ', '),
   }
-
+  local deprecate_servers = {}
   vim.list_extend(buf_lines, matching_config_header)
+  local aliased = require('lspconfig').server_alias
+  for server_name, deprecate in pairs(aliased) do
+    if deprecate.inconfig then

comment_data.body:
because available just show the server which list in configs. after deprecate there will show the new server name . like user configed `tsserver` but when they call LspInfo  available servers show `ts_ls` already.  
`config[k] = deprecate.to` there has been update.

comment_data.body: exposing this table globally means any code can modify it. When it was a function, it was read-only. Immutability is generally a good idea.

if we return the entire list we didn't encapsulate anything, and the internal list can be modified.


comment_data.body:
didn't test, but something like this should work (and is much clearer):

```suggestion
return vim.tbl_filter(function(v) return not not v.inconfig end, aliases)
```

comment_data.body:
```lua
M.server_aliases = function(name)
  if name then
    return aliases[name]
  end
  return vim
    .iter(aliases)
    :filter(function(_, v)
      return v.inconfig
    end)
    :totable()
end
```

this is work .

comment_data.body:
```lua
function vim.tbl_filter(func, t)
  vim.validate({ func = { func, 'c' }, t = { t, 't' } })
  --- @cast t table<any,any>

  local rettab = {} --- @type table<any,any>
  for _, entry in pairs(t) do
    if func(entry) then
      rettab[#rettab + 1] = entry
    end
  end
  return rettab
end

```

vim.tbl_filter just return a list-like table with value in before `t` . then the server name as k will be ignored. 

if vim.iter is not sure can we go back to normal for loop ?
